"En 1986, le philosophe Harry Frankfurt définissait le concept de “bullshit” en lui donnant un sens bien précis, traduit parfois en français sous le nom de “baratin”. Un baratineur n’est pas un menteur (qui est conscient de tromper), il est juste totalement indifférent à la vérité, ce qui le rend presque plus dangereux encore (“bullshit is a greater enemy of the truth than lies are”)" https://freakonometrics.hypotheses.org/66144 "La société du bullshit"

I think there's a strong analogy here with the work of people like Joshua Kerievsky (https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/85041.Refactoring_to_Patterns) - the design patterns or topologies are the states, the refactorings are the transitions to get into them or move between them.

The Nature of Software is my project to reconcile the later work of the architect Christopher Alexander (that is, *after* pattern languages) with the craft of software development, serialized as a newsletter. Here is the unpaywalled introduction (🔓): https://buttondown.email/natureofsoftware/archive/the-nature-of-sofwtare/

last_post.content:
Web hosting giant GoDaddy made headlines this month when it disclosed that a multi-year breach allowed intruders to steal company source code, siphon customer and employee login credentials, and foist malware on customer websites. Media coverage understandably focused on GoDaddy's admission that it suffered three different cyberattacks over as many years at the hands of the same hacking group.  But it's worth revisiting how this group typically got in to targeted companies: By calling employees and tricking them into navigating to a phishing website.

This is arguably true of most police tech:

"The use of drones as surveillance tools and first responders is a fundamental shift in policing, one that is happening without a well-informed public debate around privacy regulations, tactics, and limits for this technology."

@Patrickcsisson in Tech Review:

"https://www.technologyreview.com/2023/02/27/1069141/welcome-to-chula-vista-where-police-drones-respond-to-911-calls/"

The lesson is this: don't believe any platform "audit" that doesn't carefully simulate what real users actually do.

So far, pretty much every study has used either random clicks or bots programmed to have monomaniacal interest in something bad.

So what will work instead? On-platform experiments. We covered this in our big recommender paper last year. http://arxiv.org/abs/2207.10192
2/2

title: The Amplification Paradox in Recommender Systems

last_post.content:
New research: most previous work showing that YouTube, TikTok etc. recommend increasingly extreme content is junk 😐

These "audits" simulated users clicking randomly. But that vastly overestimates rabbit hole effects, because most users aren't extreme.

It may still be true that recsys choose content that is bad for users and for society. But the testing methods used so far aren't up to the job.

https://arxiv.org/abs/2302.11225

1/2

New study: "The strongest…predictor of perceived danger of #misinformation is the third-person effect (i.e., the perception that others are more vulnerable to misinformation than the self) and, in particular, the belief that ‘distant’ others (as opposed to family and friends) are vulnerable to misinformation. The belief that societal problems have simple solutions and clear causes was consistently, but weakly, associated with perceived danger of online misinformation."
https://psyarxiv.com/n4qrj

THIS IS THE BIGGEST STORY IN THE WORLD —

It must be told in books and articles, in movies and songs, at breakfast tables, lunch meetings, and family gatherings, in lifts, at bus stops, and in rural shops. In kindergartens and old people's homes. In hospitals and car-repair shops. On Instagram, TikTok, and the evening news. On dusty country roads and in the streets and alleys of our towns and cities.

title: Death on a Dairy Farm: What Really Happened to 8-Year-Old Jefferson Rodríguez

last_post.content:
@ProPublica fans: I urge you to read this dark, lengthy story about a child who died.

Why? Because you'll feel better afterwards.

Counterintuitive, I know. Readers are burnt out on bad news, we're told.

But burnout isn't just about bad news. It comes from a sense of powerlessness over events.

At its best, then, long-form journalism can disarm bad news — by illuminating the structural forces and human actors at play.

And this is some of the best I've read in a while.

https://www.propublica.org/article/wisconsin-dairy-farm-jefferson-rodriguez

The most fundamental clumping mechanism in #Inform7 for objects is kinds. The hierarchy is familiar to experienced I7ers: room, direction, region, and thing are the direct subkinds of object. I7 won't let you make an object whose base kind is object: if you assert `X is an object`, the compiler will infer it's some particular subkind of object. In the absence of any meaningful implications, it'll end up as a thing.

https://zedlopez.github.io/i7doc/i7prog/index.html#class-and-prejudice
